Faling to establish a network connection is *normal* and not an indication of 
a problem. Definitely not worth a stack trace, and probably not worth 
reporting at all unless the attempt to connect was initiated by user command.

I develop on a laoptp, often disconnected from the net for hours at a time, so 
I get a LOT of these.

Successful updates, on the other hand, should be logged.

Just to confirm: you have enabled automatic updates and don't want to see 
network errors while running disconnected, right ? If you were actually 
connected and there were errors, would you expect to see logged errors?

I am marking this as an enhancement, as it is not really a bug.

I would disagree that this is not a bug. It's just not a very serious one, but 
it is clearly a bug and not an enhancement. (Except in the sense that having 
fewer bugs is an enhancement! ;=).

But regardless:
If I am connected, and Comcast or some other router somewhere is out to lunch, 
or the target site has a power outage or something, no, I would not care to 
have this appear in the log! This is just a normal aspect of the environment.

Here's what I suggest: Log only successful updates (with no stack trace!). You 
can see in the log how long it has been since a successful connection. You 
COULD also warn when the site has been unavailable for an extended time, say a 
week or so.

Remember, a failed automatic connection is of little import, because it will 
be retried unti it succeeds anyway.

Foreground failures (i.e. by explicit user request from the menu item) should 
be reported immediately to the user -- but not logged on failure, only on 
success, as only the success has any impact on changing the environment.

I mostly agree with your comments, with one general exception: when somethings 
goes wrong, product support teams may need to see the error/activity log. 
Deciding what should or should not go in the log is not rocket science, but is 
not personal preferences either.

For example: for user triggered update via the ui: if something failed and the 
user must call the support line, he needs to provide some record of the 
problem, so a logged network problem would probably be good.

Making the right logging choice is less critical for infrequent events, and 
often erring on the side of extra information for support helps in the long 
run. So logging the failuire in the event of a user-initiated update doesn't 
bother me -- but it only adds value if the customer wouldn't report the 
failure reported in the dialog, and if support would make use of the 
information.

One approach is to log information like this to a separate, short-lived log. 
This can include the last several recent commands and other information which 
you would not be able to log otherwise but which might help support. 
(Efficiency becomes an issue, but a buffered log with asynchronous formatting, 
and minimal amounts of text is usually acceptable for all except things like 
mouse motion events!)

I like the idea of a log frame that logs the most recent events separately, 
although, with some pseudo chaos theory, one could argue the first, oldest 
event affects is the cause for the most recent one :-)
Anyway, this is going on a different tangent, so for now, I will leave the bug 
open and consider investigating the amount of logging during automatically 
scheduled updates.

I don't believe that automatic updates that fail should prompt the user in
regard to the failure. If the user initiated the update then by means provide
information on it failing. However, there are plenty of mobile users that will
have the machines disconnected from the network when an automatic update occurs.
It is certainly fine to leave an error icon in the lower right hand corner
allowing the user to be notified of the problem without being interuptted.

I'll add that I have had to turn off automatic updates, since it pops up a 
dialog these days. This is very much a bug, as it renders the feature unusable 
for a significant population.
